column4: Whenever I try to build something, I get: "error: C compiler cannot create executables", and the log says "/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lc". What's happening here?
hmm.. the linker is missing something
I've installed all the common tools etc I thought I'd need. Is there an easy way to tell what's missing?
a quick loko at the man page says you may be misisng /lib/crt0.o
(Sorry, I know next to nothing about development) Ok, I'll look and see if it's there…
so, lets back track, when you say build something, is this you compiling from source? or any c program
Well I definitely don't have that file there.
It's Mesa (the graphics library)
ok I think your actually missing libc.a
I'm hoping the newer version (that isn't in the 10.10 repos) will support the graphics chipset I have
run this: sudo find / -name "libc.a"
Not done searching yet but: /usr/lib/i386-linux-gnu/xen/libc.a, /usr/lib/i386-linux-gnu/libc.a
ok so you have the package, but it could be that libc.a is not in ld's search path
that last was to you. It turned out to be sort of… reflexive. D'oh! :-S
wha?
lol, I accidentally addressed a message to myself :-P  It looks like I have to edit /etc/ld.so.conf then.
(I'm looking at http://www.eyrie.org/~eagle/notes/rpath.html)
you can probably pass the extra variable you need to the make process
Oh, hmm.
I have no idea how to do that. :-P All I'm doing is running ./configure :-D
OHHH so your not even making the driver yet
Nope, didn't even get that far! :-P
do you have libc6-dev installed?
Yes, I do have libc6-dev installed.
look at the configure file, see where or how its looking for libc.a
I tried adding a line /usr/lib/i386-linux-gnu/xen/ to /etc/ld.so.conf and then running ldconfig but I got the same error.
just to make sure.. are you a 64 or 32bit OS?
32bit
the other line in /etc/ld.so.conf is include /etc/ld.so.conf.d/*.conf.
IN that folder are GL.conf@  i686-linux-gnu.conf  libasound2.conf  libc.conf
In GL.conf is /usr/lib/fglrx. In i686-linux-gnu.conf http://wklej.se/5640 In libasound2.conf is /usr/lib/alsa-lib. In libc.conf are 2 lines: "# libc default configuration" and "/usr/local/lib"
I tried adding the path to the folder containing one of those libc.a files to libc.conf and then running sudo ldconfig, but it still didn't work. Here's my complete config.log: http://wklej.se/af18
hmm.. can you check gcc's search path? maybe thats the issue
How can I check that search path?
theres some command in gcc.. I think its.. —print-search-directories? it should be in the -h output or in the man page
It's --print-search-dirs. :-) No idea what to make of the output though!! http://wklej.se/ef63
thats basically where all the components of the build process looks for things like libraries and stuff
is libc.a in any of those i686 dirs?
Yup there's one in /usr/lib/i686-linux-gnu/
Not right under but it's /usr/lib/i686-linux-gnu/xen/libc.a
ok, I forget, is that 686 directory in gcc's search path?
yup
that is weird.. lets try this… do you know how to write C programs?
nope, no idea. Only PHP and VB.Net (sorry but it's true :-D)!
im gonna write you a quick C program, I want you to test somethin for me
And I wouldn't even trust myself with those languages :-P
Cool, thanks! Just as long as it doesn't format my hard disk or something :-D
copy this into some file called whatever.c, http://pastebin.com/t650aVNy
oh ofcourse not
do you have it copied?
hehe, I was just joking. Well no actually. I'm still waiting for a browser to open — Banshee's eating up all my cpu and ram with an import :-D
Dam this is taking a long time!! Sorry! :-S
its cool brah
done: ~/yougotthatrightyo.c
ok, now run gcc -o fubar yougotthatrightyo.c
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -lc  collect2: ld returned 1 exit status
man.. there is something WEIRD with your system
(that was on two lines, the second beginning at 'collect2')
I hate when that happens. It seems to happen a *lot*. :-(
I have NEVER seen that happen before
just totally random weird sh!t.
have you tried reinstalling gcc and build-essential?
No idea why. Maybe I should uninstall and then reinstall gcc etc?
hehe, great minds think alike :-D
no I have not.
I guess that's next, so here goes!
the next thing I would try would be to, instead of using gcc, to build that c file one at a time. Basically: preprocessor, compiler, assembler, linker
before or after the reinstalls?
after if you still cant compile my file
ok
my guess is that the pp, compiler, and assembler shouldnt fail.. but the linker will.. so we may not get anymore info
Ah. That makes sense. The reinstalls might take a while; removing gcc took VirtualBox along with it :-P
oh noez
lol, howsabout I try to get audio working in the meantime??? :-D
oh God.. sound is the only thing I hate worse than X Server
Hmm, well I think my problem is that I don't have a sound card. That might explain it…
that wuld be a good freakin guess
done.
Trying again now…
Same error.
crud man.. I really dont know whats wrong.. Id hate to tell you to reinstall your OS.. but..
wow, weird, I just got logged out totally randomly.
that's the second time that's happened since yesterday
How would I go about building it one step at a time?? Sorry I'm so ignorant :-D
nah man your not ignorant, your just not a c programmer
I honestly dont think thats gonna matter.. like I said.. I think your gonna have to reinstall your system.. I have no clue what the issue is
wow. crap. I've put so much work into getting this system just the way I like it, and now to just have to scrap it all :-S There is no way that's happening :-D
what's the recommended procedure for a badly broken system?
reinstall? lol whenever my system gets f'ed up I usually switch distros

hehe, that seems a little extreme. What I'm trying (and failing) to do in the long term is start yet another ubuntu spinoff distro. Since I can't even get one install to work right — much less many — I don't think it's *quite* ready yet…
i dont think it is as much.. why would anyone use a tool they dont understand? your just asking for trouble
I was talking about switching distros.
